titleStmt.title: MS. Canon. Pat. Lat. 52
MSS. Canon. Pat. Lat. (Canonici Latin Patristic)

msDesc.head: A collection of mainly Franciscan authors, composed of seven codicological units

supportDesc.extent: ii (modern paper) + ii (parchment fragment) + 205 + ii (modern paper) leaves 180 130

decoDesc.decoNote: Space left for initials, not executed.
Spaces left for miniatures in art. 12 (fols. 69r–75r), not executed.

binding.p: Soranzo binding. Sewn on four bands laced into pulpboard covered with quarter speckled brown tanned calf and plain undecorated parchment; the spine with gilt filets and a red leather title-piece lettered in gilt capitals S. Augustinus de | cogni veræ vitæ | mag(ist)ri Barth. Bon | de Luce et alior. | Op(uscu)la Cod: membr.; the edges of the leaves speckled blue.

origin.note: Several authors have described the manuscript as Italian, probably influenced by the early Italian provenance. Beryl Smalley, for example, asserted that All the contents are written in 14th cent. Italian hands, but there are some notes in German in the same hand as the text to item no. 11, a mystical exposition of Nabuchodonosor's vision of the tree … [i.e. fols. 69r–75v] (John Russell, O.F.M., p. 285); Mossmann disputes this stating that it is incontrovertibly [south-west] German and also likely Franciscan (p. 133).

history.provenance: Canons regular of San Bartolomeo, Vicenza, 15th century: inscribed Est monasterii Sancti Bartholomei iuxta burgum Pusterlae (fol. 199v), partially effaced with ink, presumably by the next owners:

Canons regular of Santa Maria della Carità, Venice: inscribed, Statio huius libri est in quarta sede a latere canalis. Iste liber est monasterii caritatis (fol. 199v; 15th century). This house was located beside the Grand Canal in Venice. Similar inscriptions in MS. Canon. Misc. 573; MS. Lat. th. d. 28; and Aberdeen, University Library, MS 242 (Aberdeen, University Library, MS 106 has a linked provenance).
Jacopo Soranzo (1686–1761), of Venice; his binding, much of whose library was acquired by:
Matteo Luigi Canonici (1727–1805); Venetian Jesuit and bibliophile; bequeathed to his brother:
Giuseppe Canonici (d. 1807); on whose death to their nephew:
Giovanni Perisinotti (fl. c. 1807–17), from whom over 2,000 books were:

recordHist.source: Description by Peter Kidd (June 2021), building on work by Francesca Galli and Andrew Dunning. Previously described in the Quarto Catalogue (H. O. Coxe, Catalogi codicum manuscriptorum Bibliothecæ Bodleianæ pars tertia codices Græcos et Latinos Canonicianos complectens, Quarto Catalogues III, 1854). Quarto Catalogue, col. 318 Quarto Catalogue, cols. 319–20 Quarto Catalogue, col. 321 Summary Catalogue, vol. 4, p. 327

ref.title: Manuscripts from German-Speaking Lands – A Polonsky Foundation Digitization Project
Handschriftencensus: Eine Bestandsaufnahme der handschriftlichen Überlieferung deutschsprachiger Texte des Mittelalters

msItem.author: Honorius Augustodunensis (Ps.-Augustine)
msItem.title: De cognitione uerae uitae

rubric.add: Incipit liber beati Augustini de cognitione vere vite

msItem.incipit: Sapientia dei que os muti apperuit
msItem.explicit: sed spiritus sanctus corpus columbe condidit. Amen.
msItem.note: The text divided into sections by letters a–z in the margins; followed (fols. 3v–4r) by an index in rough alphabetical order (e.g. Anima precedes Amor), each entry citing the relevant marginal letter and folio number..
The heading added by a 15th-century Italian hand, perhaps over an erasure.

msItem.author: Ps.-Augustine
msItem.title: De spiritu et anima
msItem.rubric: Incipit tractatus beati Augustini de spiritu et anima. secundum quosdam
msItem.incipit: Quoniam dictum est michi ut me ipsum cognoscam
msItem.explicit: et visione dei quam cernere desiderat. Finis. Amen.
msItem.note: Each chapter marked in the margin by a letter, a–z, a–r; followed (fols. 12r–13v) by an index in rough alphabetical order (e.g. Animus precedes Anima).

msItem.author: Rudolf von Biberach (Ps.-Bonaventure)
msItem.title: De septem donis spiritus sancti
msItem.rubric: Incipit tractatus de .7. donis spiritus sancti
msItem.incipit: Omne datum optimum et omne donum perfectum de sursum est
msItem.explicit: nec agi fructuosius aliquid potest quam deo gratias.
msItem.note: The text is divided into sections by letters in the margins, restarting at a with each new chapter; running headings Prologus c. 1 – Donum 7 c. 11; followed (fols. 29r–31r) by an alphabetical index, with references citing section, chapter, and marginal letter, e.g. Convivium amicorum est 7.c.5.b refers to Donum 7, cap. 5, marginal letter b.

msItem.author: Anselm of Canterbury
msItem.title: De conceptu uirginali et de originali peccato
msItem.note: (Summary)
msItem.incipit: Ego iam concepta eram Prov. 8[:25]. Quia vero beatus Anselmus librum de virginali conceptu ad laudem virginis edidit idcirco ad colligendum virtutes illius libri
msItem.explicit: sic est in nobis de peccato originali. Ista tamen in libro dicit quod non procedit nisi coniectando
msItem.note: A series of short numbered passages, with corresponding numbers 1–36 in the adjacent margin. (Cf. Marseille, Bm, MS. 210, fol. 123r; see Catalogue générale des manuscrits, xv (Paris, 1892), p. 74.

msItem.title: Quotations from Augustine on virtue
msItem.incipit: Quis est virtus. dicit Augustinus. de civitate dei. virtus amoris ordo

msItem.author: Richard of St.-Victor
msItem.title: Beniamin maior
msItem.rubric: Rich. .4. l. de archa mist. c. 16
msItem.incipit: Sed quamvis iam parata sit tunc temporis eiusmodi anima
msItem.explicit: non solum potantur sed inebriantur. quere supra .7.c.6. a. Item .7.c.7.
msItem.note: Fols. 32v–34v are almost entirely blank except for foliation and a cropped note at the top of fol. 34v.

supportDesc.foliation: 1–36 in medieval ink in the middle of the upper margin of rectos and versos (often cropped; continued in the next section); partly replaced by a 15th(?)-century foliation in ink in the upper right corner of rectos; the latter partly overwritten in 20th-century pencil: 1–4, 5a, 5b, 6–22, 23a, 23b, 24–34

handDesc.handNote: Small gothic glossing hand, apparently written in several stages with changes of ink and perhaps also of scribe.

msItem.author: Rudolf von Biberach (Ps.-Bonaventure)
msItem.title: De septem itineribus aeternitatis
msItem.incipit: Eum qui venit ad me non eiciam foras. Io. 6[:37]. Sanctus Augustinus in libro de cognitione vere vite in principio dicit. Cum Christus veritas et vita dicat
msItem.explicit: nos perducat conducat et inducat qui est trinus et unus deus in eternum benedictus. Amen.
msItem.note: Running headings provide Iter and Distinctio numbers, e.g. Iter 4 d. 3; marginal letters of the alphabet divide them into sections.
Followed by two short notes (fol. 60r) and an alphabetical index (fols. 60r–62v):

msItem.quote: In tabula primus numerus significat itinera. secundus significat distinctiones
Qui legit ista collecta sciat quod collaciones auctoritates in diversis voluminibus variantur …

msItem.note: Pr. S.R.E. Cardinalis Bonaventuræ opera omnia, viii, ed. by A. C. Peltier (Paris 1866), pp. 393–482; repr. with intro. and corrigenda by Margot Schmidt (Stuttgart, 1985).
Stegmüller, Rép. Bibl., no. 7519.
B. Distelbrink, Bonaventurae scripta: authentica, dubia vel spuria critice recensita (Rome, 1975), pp. 124–25 no. 109.

msItem.author: Thomas Aquinas (?)
msItem.title: Sermones XXXII de sacramento corporis domini
msItem.note: (incomplete)

msItem.rubric: Modus procedendi in sermones de sacramento corporis domini
msItem.incipit: De sacro sancto corporis domini locuturi sacramento proponimus donante deo procedere tali modo
msItem.explicit: informandam vitam et devotionem excitandam.

msItem.incipit: Incipiunt tituli operis. Primus de tribus causis institutionis sacramaneti corporis Christi
msItem.explicit: 32. De triplici potu sanguinis Christi. De corporis christi sermones …

msItem.incipit: Venite comedite panem meum Prov. 9[:5] Hiis verbis dominus nos invitat ad salutare convivium
msItem.explicit: quia gratiam non contulerunt de primo. Ierem. vi holocausta [Jerem. 6:20]

msItem.note: Ending abruptly in the first sermon, despite the tituli operis for all 32 sermons.

Variously attributed: formerly pr. among the works of Albertus Magnus, Bonaventura, and others (cf. Glorieux, Maîtres, II, p. 46 no. bx; Distelbrink, op. cit., p. 185 no. 206, under dubia vel spuria), but given to Aquinas by Schneyer, Repertorium, V, p. 608 nos. 412–13.

msItem.title: Abstractum glossar
msItem.incipit: Abstractum – abgezogen vel abgescheiden
msItem.explicit: betrahtunge vel bedehtnisse vel inbildunge.
msItem.note: With spaces left for additions; some additions provided by several hands.

Volker Honemann, Das Abstractum-Glossar in der Berliner Handschrift Ms. germ. quart 765 und der Breslauer Handschrift cod. IV. Q. 92: Beschreibung der Handschriften und Edition, in Äußern und Bedeuten. Festschrift für Eckard Rolf, ed. by J. C. Freienstein, et al. (Tübingen, 2011), pp. 265–80, at 265.

In an Eastern Swabian dialect according to S. Mossmann, Otto von Passau and the literary history of Basel in the later fourteenth century, in Raum und Medium: Literatur und Kultur in Basel in Spätmittelalter und Früher Neuzeit, ed. by J. Thali and N. F. Palmer (Berlin, 2020), pp. 107–51 at 133.

msItem.title: Definitions in German of concepts in Latin
msItem.incipit: Sensus sinlichkeit oder sinneliche bewegunge ist der seleliden an dem libe
msItem.explicit: war heit ein frölich wnder.
msItem.note: Mainly concerning concepts relating to the mind: sensus, ymaginacio, cogitacio, consideracio, meditacio, ingenium, ratio, intellectus, intelligencia, contemplacio, caritas, memoria, etc.
Miscellaneous short notes, including:
msItem.incipit: Nota. Augustinus dicitur habuisse virtutes cardinales
Anselmus. Suscipe domine de mea misera vița residuum annorum meorum
Augustinus. Contemplativa vita amabilis valde dulcedo est
Ambrosius: Confessio a morte liberat paradisum aperit
Gregorius. Ad fidem plures veniunt ad celeste regnum pauci perducuntur
Ysidorus. Orationibus mundamur lectionibus instruimur
Gullielmus. Nihil honestius habeas vel si habeas ad libertatem conferre
Hugo. Spes est fiducia futurorum bonorum ex gratia
Beda. Qui vult assequi eternam beatitudinem

msItem.note: blank

supportDesc.foliation: 35–45, 46a–b, 47–66, 67a–b, 68 in modern pencil (used here), over-writing a 15th(?)-century foliation, and superseding a medieval foliation which continues from the previous text at 37 but ends at 45

layoutDesc.layout: Two columns of about 57 lines (fols. 64v–66v in three columns), c. 160 120

handDesc.handNote: Small gothic hands of varying care and skill, with some cursive features

msContents.textLang: Latin with Middle High German (East Swabian dialect)

msItem.author: Ps.-Bonaventure
msItem.title: Arbor amoris
msItem.note: with embedded Minnebaumsprüche
msItem.incipit:
Videbam et ecce arbor in medio terre altitudo eius nimia
[cf. Dan. 4:7–9] Arbor hec est amor dei quam plantavit deus in medio terre Medium terre est cor hominis de quo procedit tam terrene quam celestis uirtus operacionis
msItem.explicit: In .7. habet dulce colloquium cum ipso. Explicit.
msItem.note: Twenty-seven spaces are left within the columns of text for diagrams or miniatures; next to each are captions in Latin and German.
See J. Theben, Die mystische Lyrik des 14. und 15. Jahrhunderts: Untersuchungen – Texte – Repertorium (Berlin, 2010), pp. 47, 252 n. 432, 262, 482.
msItem.bibl: Cf. text pr. Urse Kamber, Arbor amoris, der Minnebaum : ein Pseudo-Bonaventura-Traktat (Berlin, 1964), 44-59
msItem.note: In an Eastern Swabian dialect according to Mossman, op. cit., 133.

msItem.author: Conrad Holtnicker
msItem.title: Speculum beatae Mariae uirginis
msItem.incipit: Quoniam vero ait beatus Iheronimus. Nulli dubium est quin totum ad gloriam laudis dei pertineat
msItem.explicit: ille liberalissimus communicator sui benedictus fructus ventris tui qui cum patre … secula seculorum amen.
msItem.note: Foliated and divided into uneven sections by letters in the margins, a–t, a–z, a–r, a–y, a–z, a–f.
Followed (fols. 94r–96r) by an alphabetical index, ending Explicit tabula super Ave Maria.
Speculum Beatae Mariae Virginis Fr. Conradi a Saxonia, ed. L. Schmitz (Quaracchi, 1904).
Distelbrink, Bonaventurae scripta, 214; Glorieux Répertoire, ii, no. 305dp; Stegmüller, Rép. Bibl., nos. 2016–17.

msItem.author: Bartholomaeus Bononiensis
msItem.title: De luce
msItem.rubric: Incipit tractatus magistri Bartholomei Bononiensis de luce
msItem.incipit: Ego sum lux mundi [John 8:12]. Cum nos inveniamus lucem, lumen, radium splendorem et inter hec reperire contingat proprietatum diversitatem
msItem.explicit: et spiritualiter interpretari relinquuntur ad presens maiori investigacioni vel saltem alteri tempori. Et hec sufficiant. Amen.
msItem.note: Without the preface. Followed (fol. 99r–v) by an alphabetical index headed Incipit tabula super eodem tractatu id est de luce
Foliated 22–25 (continued from the previous text), and divided into uneven sections by letters in the margins, a–z.
ed. Francesca Galli, Il «De luce» di Bartolomeo da Bologna: Studio e edizione, Micrologus Library, 104 (Florence, 2021)
Glorieux Répertoire, ii, no. 319a (citing only 3 MSS., including the present one, as Canonic. lat. script. eccl. 62.
Blank.

supportDesc.foliation: 69–100 in modern pencil (used here), overwriting a late medieval foliation ink ink and superseding a medieval ink foliation 1–25 (partly cropped) starting at fol. 75.

layoutDesc.layout: Frame-ruled in ink for two columns of about 58 lines, c. 147 95

msItem.author: John Russell
msItem.title: Commentary on the Song of Songs
msItem.incipit: Osculetur &c. Cogitanti mihi canticum promere laudis cuiusdam ad homorem virginis amorose
msItem.explicit: que illuc post filium tuum ascendisti sicut virgula fumi ex aromatibus mirre et thuris. explicit.
msItem.note: Chapter numbers [1]–8 as running headings (often cropped).
Stegmüller, Rép. Bibl., nos. 4919, 5028; Sharpe, Handlist, p. 305, listing only 5 MSS. including the present one.

Mossman, op. cit., at pp. 132–135, and 140; part of fol. 101va is pr. in ibid. p. 134, and fol. 110vb at p. 135. See also B. Smalley, John Russell, O.F.M., RTAM, 23 (1956), 277–320, briefly describing the present MS. at p. 285.

layoutDesc.layout: Two columns of about 58 lines, c. 143 100

msItem.author: Hugh of Saint-Victor
msItem.title: De laude caritatis

msItem.incipit: Servo Christi Petro, Hugo Gustare et videre quoniam suavis est dominus. Cogitanti michi frate karissime
msItem.explicit: recompensatur.

msItem.incipit: Tam multos iam laudatores habuisse cognoscitur
msItem.explicit: et mansionem in nobis facere dignetur. qui cum eodem patre et spiritu sancto per omnia secula seculorum. Amen.
msItem.note: ed. H. B. Feiss & P. Sicard, L’œuvre de Hugues de Saint-Victor, i (Turnhout, 1997)
Listed among about 100 MSS. by R. Goy, Die Überlieferung der Werke Hugos von St. Viktor (Stuttgart, 1976), pp. 253–67, at 262.
Note on the love of God
msItem.incipit: Nota de amore dei siue dilectione caritativa. Primo, qualiter sit virtus. Secundo
msItem.note: Continued on fol. 143v, as indicated by a note on fol. 126v: p(roximo?) folio 18 … signum┌.

msItem.author: Thomas Gallus
msItem.title: Commentary on the Song of Songs

rubric.add: expositio tercia venerabilis magistri Thome abbatis Verellen’ canonici regularis

msItem.incipit: In hoc glorietur qui gloriatur scire et nosse me Ier. 9. Duplex designatur hic dei cognitio
Osculetur me osculo oris sui Cor. 5. Dum sumus in corpore peregrinamur a domino [II Cor. 5:6]
msItem.explicit: et in hoc verbo petitionum suarum cursum sponsa consummat in quo perpetuo perseverat
msItem.finalRubric: Finitur tractatus abbatis Vercell’ super cantica. deo gratias.
msItem.note: ed. J. Barbet, Commentaires du Cantique des cantiques, Textes philosophiques du moyen âge, 14 (1967), pp. 107–232.
Stegmüller, Rép. Bibl., no. 8201.

msItem.title: Note on the love of God (continued from fol. 126v)
msItem.note: Preceded by a corresponding symbol ┌. and note, require in secundo folio prioris sexterni per rem precedentem.
msItem.explicit: posset deum diligere si eum quem diligit non haberet.

msItem.author: Richard of St.-Victor
msItem.title: Beniamin minor

msItem.incipit: 1 – De studio sapiencie et eius comendacione
msItem.explicit: 87 vel quomodo meditatio surgat ad comtemplationem.

msItem.incipit: Beniamin adolescentulus in mentis excessu [Ps. 67:28] Audiant adolescentuli sermones de adolescente, evigilent ad vocem prophete
msItem.explicit: et deosculatione Beniamin et Joseph divine revelationi humana racio applaudit.

msItem.author: Thomas Gallus
msItem.title: De septem gradibus contemplationis
msItem.incipit: Contemplativorum aquilinos obtusus acui et ipsorum spirituale palatum perfundi dapibus superne dulcedinis affectans
msItem.explicit: pudissimo wltu blandiebatur castissimo amplexu complexa est dominum nostrum Ihesum Christum, qui est benedictus in secula seculorum. Amen.
msItem.note: ed. Peltier, Bonaventurae Opera Omnia, xii (1868), pp. 183–86.
Distelbrink, Bonaventurae scripta, p. 123 no. 107; Glorieux, Répertoire, i, p. 273 no. 116g.

msItem.author: Hugh of St.-Victor
msItem.title: Soliloquium de arra animae

msItem.note: (fols. 164v)
Prologue
msItem.incipit: Ut discamus ubi nos oporteat verum amatorem querere
msItem.explicit: ad superna gaudia excitare
msItem.note: Four lines only, filling a space at the bottom of a column, followed by an added marginal note quere in fine libri invenis prefationem completam; the hand of this note has added the preface at fol. 199r (see below)

msItem.incipit: Loquar anime mee secreto et amica confabulacione exigam
msItem.explicit: hoc totis precordiis concupisco fiat fiat amen.
msItem.note: Much of fol. 169v is blank; the rest of the quire has added texts written in a single column.

msItem.incipit: Cum in nocte video in choro conventum ad laudandum dominum quemlibet intentum
msItem.explicit: Quam infundit largiter anime petenti. Explicit Iubilus monachorum amen.
msItem.note: Variously titled in other MSS. e.g. Torneamentum monachorum, Torneamentum religiosorum.
Pr. Serapeum: Zeitschrift für Bibliothekswissenschaft, Handschriftenkunde und ältere Literatur, 17 (1856), 285–87.
Chevalier 4075 citing only the present MS.; WIC 3634.

msItem.author: Ecbertus Schonaugiensis
msItem.title: Soliloquium I
msItem.rubric: Incipit soliloquium beati [the name overwritten with:] Richardi
msItem.incipit: Verbum secretum est michi ad te o rex seculorum Christe Ihesu
msItem.explicit: desideriabilis domine ubi extra te requiescent desideria mea. quere prima.
msItem.note: Ending before the end of Soliloquy I as pr. (among the works of Richard of Saint-Victor) in PL, cxcv, 105–07 (cf. PL, clviii, 773–79, in which it is treated as the beginning of Anselm’s Meditatio XIII); on the authorship see A. Wilmart, La tradition des prières de Saint Anselme: Tables et notes, Rev. bénéd., xxxvi (1924), at 59–60.
Cf. fols. 197r–198r below. Also present in MS. Canon. Pat. Lat. 13, fol. 108r

msItem.title: Sermon
msItem.incipit: Petite et accipietis ut gaudium vestrum plenum sit Jo. 16[:24] Sciendum quod omni(?) eterna beatitudine cuiuslibet
msItem.explicit: omni timoris amissione. Amen
msItem.note: Fols. 171v–172v blank

layoutDesc.layout: 2 cols of 58 lines, c. 145 95 ; the added texts (fols. 170r–171r) in a single column, c. 150 95

msItem.author: Aegidius Romanus
msItem.title: Commentary on the Song of Songs
msItem.incipit: Osculetur me osculo oris sui &c. Intentio principalis huius operis est exprimere mutua desideria inter sponsum et sponsam
msItem.explicit: et in futura secundum visionem apertam comprehensorum dignetur nobis dare deus qui est benedictus in secula seculorum. Amen. Expliciunt postilla super Cantica edite ab Egidio.
msItem.note: Without the prologue.
ed. Sancti Thomae Aquinatis Doctoris Angelici ordinis praedicatorum Opera omnia, xiv: Expositio in aliquot libros veteris testamenti (Parma, 1863), pp. 389–426.
Glorieux, Répertoire des maîtres, ii, p. 303 no. 400aw (and unde Thomas Aquinas, op. cit., i, pp. 101–02 no. 14eq ); Stegmüller, Rép. Bibl., 911 (citing the present MS.).
Brief added note listing the lengths of the first five Ages of the World (from Adam to Christ)
msItem.incipit: Prima etas ad Adam usque ad Noe .M.600 anni
msItem.explicit: summa .5.M.800 et .8. anni.
msItem.note: Fols. 186r–188v are blank.

supportDesc.support: paper except for the outermost and innermost bifolium

msItem.author: Bertramnus de Alen
msItem.title: De laude Domini novi saeculi

msItem.incipit: Triplici pater reverende existente gaudio novi seculi secundum triplex genus cognicionis
msItem.explicit: inter multa verbum aliquod adiungendum.

msItem.incipit: Duplici igitur existente ymnoloya [i.e. hymnologia] divina
msItem.explicit: Sed haec expertis et passis huius plenius pertractando relinquo.
msItem.note: Ed. A. Beccarisi, Texte aus der Zeit Meisters Eckhart, I: Bertram von Ahlen, Opera (Hamburg, 2004), pp. 9–42, compared to which the present MS. lacks the short salutation at the beginning of the prologue (Reverendo patri sacrae theologiae magistro fratri Gerardo ministro Coloniensi frater Bertramus de Alen …); chapter I runs straight on from, and is treated as a continuation of the prologue (MS. line 13, edn. line 20); and ends near the end of Gradus II, chapter VII (edn. p. 42 l. 15), thus lacking ch. 8–15.

msItem.author: Hugh of St.-Victor
msItem.title: De arca morali
msItem.incipit: In fine precedentibis libri per similitudinem cuiusdam arboris demonstravimus qualiter sapientia oriatur et crescat in nobis
msItem.explicit: Nunc ergo ad propositum revertentes de fabricatione arche sapiencie prosequamur. Explicit tertius.
msItem.note: ed. P. Sicard, CCCM, 176 (2001), pp. 55–85.

msItem.author: Ecbertus Schonaugiensis
msItem.title: Soliloquium I
msItem.incipit: Verbum michi est ad te o princeps seculorum Christe Ihesu
msItem.explicit: inviolabile decus et regnum solidum pernamens in secula seculorum Amen.
msItem.note: PL, cxcv, 105–14; cf. fol. 170r above for further references.
The second column of fol. 198v blank.

msItem.author: Hugh of St.-Victor
msItem.title: Soliloquium de arra animae
msItem.rubric: Incipit prefatio Hugonis de S. Victore in libellum de arra anime
msItem.incipit: Dilecto fratri G. ceterisque servis Christi carissimus leve [? recte Hamerisleve] degentibus Hugo qualiscumque vestre sanctitatis servus
msItem.explicit: omnia tamen in libro vite conscribi exopto. Explicit prefatio incipit liber tractatus
msItem.note: Item added in an Italian humanist cursive hand. Most of the page is blank.
List of contents

Liber de spiritu et anima beati Augustini, folio quarto
Liber siue tractatus de septem donis spiritus sancti, folio 14º

Liber sive tractatus de itineribus eternitatis, folio 37º
Inceptio tractatus de corpore Christi, folio 65º
Vocabularium parvum, 66 folio
Expositio arboris Danielis spiritualis, 73º folio
Expositio super Ave Maria que dicitur viridarium uirginis, 79º
Tractatus magistri Bartholomei de luce. Ego sum lux mundi, 100º
Expositio bona et subtilis super Cantica, 105º
Item Expositio Vercellensis super Cantica, folio 131º
Tractatus de laudibus caritatis, 129º
Tractatus Richardi de 12 patriarchis vel de contemplatione, 147º
Tractatus de 7 gradibus contemplationibus brevis, 166º
Soliloquium Hugonis, folio 167º
Iuibilus monachorum, 173º
Sermo dominica 5ª post Pascham petite etc., 173º
Postilla super Cantica fratris Egidii, 176º
Soliloquium Richardi

altIdentifier.idno: MS. Canon. Pat. Lat. 52, fols. iii–iv (flyleaves)

msItem.title: Grammatical treatise on barbarismi
msItem.incipit: Item queritur. quare isti nomina. domus. humus. et milicia respondentur ad modum propriorum nominum. ad hoc dicimus quod cum dico ubi es. domi debet intelligi de domo propria.
msItem.explicit: Temporis ut siquis teos producta persona. sillaba et correcta posteriore pronunciet.
msItem.note: Opening example also in Oxford, Lincoln College, MS. 130.
Non-consecutive leaves. Most of fol. iv recto, and all of the verso, blank.

supportDesc.collation: Formed through a repair into a conjoint bifolium.

decoDesc.decoNote: Coloured initials and paraphs, alternating between red and blue.

revisionDesc.change: Andrew Dunning Updated description from Peter Kidd.

Mitch Fraas Provenance and acquisition information added using https://github.com/littlegustv/oxfordupdates/blob/master/test_case_for_oxford_prov.rb in collaboration with the Mapping Manuscript Migrations project.
James Cummings Up-converted the markup using https://github.com/jamescummings/Bodleian-msDesc-ODD/blob/master/convertTolkien2Bodley.xsl
